natural problem: Daniel has exactly $20$ pieces of candy. He has to divide them equally among his $3$ sisters. What is the least number of pieces he should take away so that he could distribute the candy equally?
natural solution: When you divide $20$ by $3$, you get $6$ with a remainder of $2$.
Therefore, he should take away $\boxed{2 \text{ pieces}}$ so he could give each of his sisters $6$ pieces.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes candies :: nat and sisters :: nat
assumes h0 : "candies = 20"
and h1 : "sisters = 3"
shows  "\<exists> n. (candies - n) mod sisters = 0 \<and> n = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Daniel has exactly $20$ pieces of candy. He has to divide them equally among his $3$ sisters. What is the least number of pieces he should take away so that he could distribute the candy equally? The final Answer is 2 \text{ pieces}
 ### Proof
 When you divide $20$ by $3$, you get $6$ with a remainder of $2$.
 Therefore, he should take away $\boxed{2 \text{ pieces}}$ so he could give each of his sisters $6$ pieces.
 *)

theorem
fixes candies :: nat and sisters :: nat
assumes h0 : "candies = 20"
and h1 : "sisters = 3"
shows  "\<exists> n. (candies - n) mod sisters = 0 \<and> n = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Is it possible to remove 2 candies from a total of 20 candies so that they can be evenly distributed among 3 sisters?

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes candy :: nat
assumes h0 : "candy = 20"
and h1 : "\<exists> x. candy - x mod 3 = 0"
shows  "x = 2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Daniel has exactly $20$ pieces of candy. He has to divide them equally among his $3$ sisters. What is the least number of pieces he should take away so that he could distribute the candy equally? The final Answer is 2 \text{ pieces}
 ### Proof
 When you divide $20$ by $3$, you get $6$ with a remainder of $2$.
 Therefore, he should take away $\boxed{2 \text{ pieces}}$ so he could give each of his sisters $6$ pieces.
 *)

theorem
fixes candy :: nat
assumes h0 : "candy = 20"
and h1 : "\<exists> x. candy - x mod 3 = 0"
shows  "x = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: "If you have 20 candies and you want to distribute them equally among a group of friends where the number of friends is a multiple of 3, how many friends must you invite? The final answer is 2."

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes candy :: nat
assumes h0 : "candy = 20"
and h1 : "candy mod 3 = 0"
shows  "candy - 2 = 18"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Daniel has exactly $20$ pieces of candy. He has to divide them equally among his $3$ sisters. What is the least number of pieces he should take away so that he could distribute the candy equally? The final Answer is 2 \text{ pieces}
 ### Proof
 When you divide $20$ by $3$, you get $6$ with a remainder of $2$.
 Therefore, he should take away $\boxed{2 \text{ pieces}}$ so he could give each of his sisters $6$ pieces.
 *)

theorem
fixes candy :: nat
assumes h0 : "candy = 20"
and h1 : "candy mod 3 = 0"
shows  "candy - 2 = 18"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: You have 20 candies. After eating 2 candies, you want to divide the remaining candies evenly among 3 friends. Is it possible? The final answer is yes, it's possible and each friend will receive 6 candies.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes candy_pieces sisters :: nat
assumes h0 : "candy_pieces = 20"
and h1 : "sisters = 3"
shows  "EX take_away :: nat. candy_pieces mod sisters = 0 \<and> take_away \<le> candy_pieces \<and> (candy_pieces - take_away) mod sisters = 0"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Daniel has exactly $20$ pieces of candy. He has to divide them equally among his $3$ sisters. What is the least number of pieces he should take away so that he could distribute the candy equally? The final Answer is 2 \text{ pieces}
 ### Proof
 When you divide $20$ by $3$, you get $6$ with a remainder of $2$.
 Therefore, he should take away $\boxed{2 \text{ pieces}}$ so he could give each of his sisters $6$ pieces.
 *)

theorem
fixes candy_pieces sisters :: nat
assumes h0 : "candy_pieces = 20"
and h1 : "sisters = 3"
shows  "EX take_away :: nat. candy_pieces mod sisters = 0 \<and> take_away \<le> candy_pieces \<and> (candy_pieces - take_away) mod sisters = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: "If there are 20 pieces of candy and they need to be divided evenly among 3 sisters, is there a number of pieces that can be taken away such that the remaining pieces can still be evenly divided among the sisters?"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_candies :: nat and num_sisters :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_candies = 20"
and h1 : "num_sisters = 3"
shows  "total_candies mod num_sisters = 2"
a_4.formal solution:

fixes total_candies :: nat and num_sisters :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_candies = 20"
and h1 : "num_sisters = 3"
shows  "total_candies mod num_sisters = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: "If there are 20 candies to be divided equally among 3 sisters, how many candies will be left over? The final answer is 2."
